q1: All in-person lectures and small groups
q4: Zoom format allows vast interactive features when given appropriate time to set up; although the more interactive the lecture, the less content can be taught.
q12_explain: For unknown reasons, there was significantly more attendance and participation during virtual office hours during the 100% remote time period
q16: There are lots of benefits to teaching virtually but those benefits cannot be experienced if faculty does not have at least double the time to prepare and build out a solid virtual format.

q1: All virtual course

q1: All in-person lectures and small groups
q4: I have little experience. I taught PCC virtually. As a "consumer" ZOOM was much more convenient, but personal interaction was poor.
q12_explain: I no longer perform surgery, but it adversely affected the education of students by our division members.
q16: It's not possible to teach or observe physical exam skills via ZOOM. It was not possible to split the group up.

q1: All in-person lectures and small groups
q4: Only slightly less interactive than in person, but just with a less intimate and enthusiastic feel
q12_explain: In some ways it was beneficial in helping connect to students who are not currently in town. But as above, it just didn't feel like I could get to know them as effectively and efficiently as in person.

q1: All in-person lectures and small groups

q1: All in-person lectures and small groups
q4: Zoom lectures can be quite interactive, but this takes substantially more time than an equivalent in-person session, so the process seemed less efficient.

q1: All in-person lectures and small groups
q4: The zoom format for our large group lectures were very well designed. They included virtual breakout rooms, which allowed students to discuss the material as if they were in person.
q16: It was slightly more difficult to make sure I circulated among the zoom rooms equally, but otherwise it was not a burden.

q4: low with large groups

q1: Recorded lecture and in-person small groups
q4: The chat is well used, and in breakout groups, students speak and have cameras on.

q1: All in-person lectures and small groups
q4: Pretty good; students are interactive when prompted and asking questions on their own.
q16: Overall, it worked well for large lecture classes, but not well for small group classes that were taught in large group. This was more organizational than an inherent problem with virtual teaching (i.e one instructor talked too much that didn't leave sufficient time for all of the material to be discussed).
